awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium: A High Performance Computing Foundation to Whole-Genome Prediction
awd_abstract_narration:
The premise of personalized medicine is based on prediction of an individual's genetic risk to disease. Modern animal and plant breeding programs select individuals or lines based on genotypic information which circumvents the costly process of progeny testing, leading to greater efficiency. In these scientific areas, the ability to translate genotypic information into a quantitative prediction of the risk to disease or breeding targets is a matter of utmost importance. To address the technical barriers in the prediction using a whole-genome sample of genetic markers, there is urgent need for new statistical models and high performance computing foundations that allow the concurrent use of millions of genetic markers and a large variety of variables describing a disease (or a breeding target). This project proposes to solve several such barriers by an integrative approach combining and developing techniques for data reduction, parallel computing and Bayesian inference. This interdisciplinary project provides educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to get first-hand research experience in computational aspects of genomics data analysis.

This project aims to understand how genome-wide markers help to predict not-yet-specified phenotypes of individuals and how the total genetic contribution can be better estimated for a phenotype. The primary goals of the proposed research are to develop: (1) parallel algorithms to reduce data that comprises millions of genetic markers into lower dimensions; (2) sparse predictive modeling with correction for the uneven tagging issue due to linkage disequilibrium; (3) fast algorithms for multi-locus mapping problems; and (4) collaborative prediction methods to jointly predict multiple phenotypes. The proposed solutions will be tested in the analysis of large-scale biological data, including a dairy cattle database collected by US Department of Agriculture and a dataset aggregated from multiple genetic studies of human diseases. This project will yield user-friendly software tools that can be broadly deployed to biological research areas that study genetics of complex phenotypes. The validated methods and software will be disseminated through the PI's laboratory website.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to translate genotype information into a quantitative prediction of phenotypes is important to advance a variety of research fields, such as precision medicine, but also imposes challenges to computational and machine learning methods. The subject of this study is to examine and lift the barriers that limit the utility of a genomic prediction method.   The project was successful, and new algorithms and evaluation performance were reported in nine journal articles and over eight juried conference papers.

(1)           Because existing predictive modeling methods may be difficult to cope with voluminous genomic data, we developed parallel and distributed optimization algorithms to improve the efficiency of training a predictive model. Particularly two methods were developed to first parallelize a first-order (gradient-based) optimization method using a double-layer asynchronous updating scheme and then parallelize a second-order (quasi-Newton) stochastic method. Because a class of gradient-based methods, called adaptive gradient methods (e.g, Adam), was commonly used to train large-scale deep learning models, we also improved their convergence by calibrating the adaptive learning rate used by such a method.    

(2)           Existing genomic prediction methods focus on the accuracy of phenotype prediction, but hardly discover genetic effects. We developed effective sparse predictive methods to identify or select genetic markers from genomic data that are most important to the prediction of a phenotype. Particularly, an effective hard thresholding method was designed based on stochastic variance reduction for nonconvex sparse learning. Another efficient randomized algorithm was also developed capable of feature selection.

(3)           Heritability is a population-level parameter measuring how much variance in a phenotype can be accounted for by genomic effects. The accuracy of a genomic prediction model for a phenotype essentially reflects the heritability of the phenotype. We developed a type of heritable component analysis tool that identifies principal components of a multivariate phenotype that are highly heritable, in other words, that refines multivariate phenotypes for high chip heritability.

(4)           Genetic association and prediction models need to allow commonality and heterogeneity in genetic effects between correlated phenotypes. We followed multi-task learning principles to design collaborative prediction methods that can predict multiple response variables (phenotypes) based on sparse models that select most relevant features (or genetic markers). First we derived a multiplicative multi-task feature selection algorithm, and then designed a bi-convex optimization method to learn classifiers when the class labels vary at different measurements.

(5)           Besides the genomic prediction models, we also combined both the genomic information and other correlated phenotypes to predict a phenotype in a single combined model. Particularly, we used matrix completion techniques to develop a collaborative phenotype inference from comorbid disorders and genotypes.

(6)           We also designed methods to deal with the complex nature of phenotypic observations, particularly a phenotype that may need to be inferred from repeated measurements of multiple parameters over a time window. We proposed a new longitudinal data analytic method - latent sparse modeling of longitudinal multi-dimensional data.

This project partially supported four postdoc researchers and eight PhD students' research, including four students' dissertation research. Among them, two postdoc researchers successfully identified tenure-track faculty positions at a four-year college or university and two other postdoc fellows pursued other academic positions (e.g., research professorship). Three PhD students have graduated, all working as data science experts currently in giant IT and AI companies. The project also supported four undergraduate researchers via its REU supplement, and two of them contributed to the publications.
